aYI5H-o1WUssR2rnl_Ji9Q.text: Wow. I ordered a salted beef sandwich and it was absolutely incredible. I went for lunch and there was plenty of room to sit. The atmosphere was nice where many people seemed to just be talking to strangers and interacting. The food spoke for itself though and I will definitely be going back.

to3uTN4yVr2T-3E5fxzP1A.text: Really delicious matzo ball soup. It's not on the menu, but they definitely have it prepared. The matzo balls are tender and moist, which is why it is better than the rest.

H4nSlTzovx-R4XojxAinMQ.text: Number one choice for an authentic, kosher, salt beef sandwich in London. Based right in the heart of Baker St, it's got just what you need after a long day. If you're feeling particularly swanky, head downstairs to the restaurant for some perfectly cooked steak.

iVVmkSmj9fZ5eeO03KoS3A.text: My first Jewish Deli experience in London -- oh so worth it!  I came here in search of a Reuben.  I'd heard it was good and had to taste it for myself.  You know you're in the right place for Reubens when a staff person is cutting up the brisket and laying the slices on the bread for expediting.I asked for a Reuben and the staff asked me how I'd like it.  I told them on rye bread, sauerkraut, and russian dressing.  The staff person said they didn't have any russian dressing and that they would have to make it.  The nice lady cutting the brisket said she'd make some.  See...?  Right there.  That's how you take care of a customer!  I waited patiently while she constructed the behemoth of a sandwich.  It was a double decker sandwich with enough meat for two, maybe three sandwiches, along with a bit of English mustard, pickles, and tomato.  What a delight!Overall, it was a FANTASTIC sandwich, and great service to match.  I also got 10% off from Yelp, which was a nice added touch!  Will I be back?  Hell Yes!Oh, and by the way...Totally killed the sandwich in preparation for a post-lunch coma...!

RhCEtfGv6bRZZePOdDo8kA.text: Never go here. Food is stale, employees obviously hate working here and hate anyone trying to eat here as it greatly disturbs their do nothing.If it wasn't kosher (which I can only hope it is) they would be out of business a long time ago.

KgRb-AkkwXvKutbr5as-NQ.text: Wow can't move after the Reubens sandwich - everyone has to try it once. Allow extra room by loosening your belt.

OoJAeN15gtXqpn3CduS11g.text: NEVER DINE HERE!Reuben's is by far the worst place. Ever.I peered through the kitchen window and was disgusted by what I witnessed.I can't believe they call this restaurant kosher. I highly doubt the food is kosher and the owners Jewish although they claim to be. There was no rabbinical supervision at all and the chef did not cover his hair. The salads were literally 5 pieces of lettuce. Nothing else was on the plate. I also ordered a soup which was way too salty. I ordered the grilled chicken entrée and a steak entrée, both of which were drowned in salt and garlic to mask the bitterness. The chicken was rubbery and the steak was overcooked and so hard and rough in texture. They brought out the wrong chicken entrée and when I let them know it was not what I had ordered the owner began to yell at me and tell me I was wrong. She showed me attitude and embarrassed in front of everyone. I couldn't believe it. Service was slow and served with much attitude. They never asked us if we needed anything throughout the meal. We didn't even have napkins at our table. They tried to add things to our bill which we had never ordered and when we asked to take home our leftovers to give to a homeless person, they brought it to us in a dirty, used container. The owner's daughter who was waiting tables, was unbelievably nasty and rude and unprofessional. I have never been treated like this at any establishment in my whole life. If you are looking for kosher food, forget about Reuben's. It was the worst experience of my life and I wish I could take back this experience. Do yourself a favour and stay away.

-Y9ibMkkTVxkLEob3Lk7xg.text: *Review for the salt beef ONLY*Hmmm.... I'd heard and read such good things. I was actually cycling home down Baker St and saw Reubens on my right. I've been craving a salt beef sandwich fix for some time and so I hit the brakes (nearly causing a crash no less), tied up the bike and went in. Saw the salt beef under the heater, it looked good. I was salivating!Ordered salt beef on rye. Fairly stingy serving of beef went in the sandwich. I was a little disappointed to watch him make it actually. No love, no stacking of the beef. Certainly nothing like NYC. Oh well. I go to pay. "That'll be £8.75". Whaaaaat? For the sandwich I've just seen your colleague make? Really? Or is mine still yet to be made and will be twice the size and adorned with pickles? No? Oh. Well. Err... here's the money then. Ouch. I asked for a pickle. Was told they're £2 each. Was now sulking.It wasn't even that good if I'm honest. Certainly not as good as Brass Rail in Selfridges. And they're 3 minutes walk from each other. It's a no brainer.

Y8cp-5MQkhhmC4fiKfxoAA.text: Way Overrated. Ordered two corned beef sandwiches to go on rye bread.  The sandwiches were the thinnest corned beef sandwiches I have ever seen in my life. When I asked if the sandwiches included pickles the gentleman said "no, you need to pay for the pickle."  I decided that I just had to have a dill pickle or two to complement the sandwich so I told him to charge me for the pickles. To my dismay when I got back to my hotel to eat the sandwich the pickles were SWEET GERKINS which were horrible. Had to throw them out. Worst part is that I had to pay 20 British Pounds and 10 Pence which is the equivalent of $30.00. When I didn't have the 10 Pence, the woman made me break a 10 pound note. They just couldn't overlook 10 Pence. Other comments about this kosher restaurant---floors were sticky and there were storage cartons strewn within sight of the diners. Just looked tacky---no class.  Don't waste your money. Reuben's is a kosher restaurant with 'attitude'---will never ever frequent this restaurant again.

1dA10g_qQIKhZV1SNQdrtw.text: 5 stars just for the matzah ball soup. It is the best!  Its a huge portion and tasty. We also get the tuna sandwich. I can't wait to try more!

NlAa7FQ_vO9v6n1k8F0nAA.text: No barrels of cucumbers or herring pickling...No bagels that I could see, nor salamis hanging from the ceiling...No pastrami, but salt beef... (corned beef for our American friends)Enough kvetching already. This is a Glatt kosher deli / restaurant in central London ... I had to try.For a restaurant, the salt beef is spectacular. Thickly sliced right in front of you, no fat whatsoever. Not as good as your grandmother's, obviously.Next, the chicken soup. kneidlach + lokshen. (matzo ball + noodles).Well, it deserves cookie points for existing. Now, the chicken stock was a bit too concentrated, and lacking vegetables. Strangely yellow too... hard to imagine it as a full chicken or schmaltz stock... Unless the chicken was actually dyed yellow...The kneidlach were moist but seemed to have a bit too much egg yoke for my taste. Overall, a good sample of somebody else's grandmother recipe, I am sure.The menu boasting things like barley and beans soup, beef tongue or gefilte fish, I'll have to come back. No herring though );As noted by previous reviewers, you'll find no Reuben sandwich here.The law clearly says: "put cheese on your beef, and you'll burn in hell". In the present case, the salt beef is so good, that if you think it needs Swiss cheese, you truly deserve your place in a bottomless pit.Note from the editor : the pastrami on rye bread sandwich is a New York thing. Salt beef on cumin bread is perfectly kosher too ;) Get over it.Finally, if you read all of that and are British, I just have to ask...Deep fried gefilte fish? really? Even in Louisiana they haven't dared...Is it any good?

v1BPtp1Dho11pY7rBdmawQ.text: Attentive service, great food, though a bit expensive. Hadn't had Beef Wellington in about 20 years, tried it here, steak perfectly cooked, pastry crust was flaky without being crunchy hard, and the gravy was worth soaking up with extra bread. Side of broccoli was good but I would have enjoyed it even more if it been steamed slightly less. Sticky toffee pudding for dessert was wonderful and nicely sized without being heavy.Service was good, though a bit overly solicitous at times, yet very friendly without being stuffy. Downstairs dining area much nicer than upstairs.It's kosher, and converting from British Pounds to US Dollars made it expensive (blame the US currency, very weak at the time I ate here). I would definitely go agian.

YGMXo0_L0lwoluOBpwjwHQ.text: GOOD SANDWICH, OBNOXIOUS STAFF, TERRIBLE VALUE. The staff take the term 'self-service' to a whole new level. They are inflexible and cannot do enough to be unhelpful and begrudging. Their English is poor and they look unhappy to be there. There are no menus. After shoe-horning ourselves round one of the tightly packed tables, we had to then go back to the front door to look at the confusingly laid out menu on a big TV. (Headings were 'chicken' and 'meat' rather than 'starters' and 'mains'). We took my parents for Sunday lunch when visiting us for the weekend. Waitress led us though the slightly busy ground floor ad hoc seating and down to the more formal area downstairs. She turned the lights on for us as we were the only souls there. We turned around and headed back upstairs. Tables are set up for 4 and we received no help rearranging for a 5th chair. I went to order some drinks and was told I had to pay there and then. Drinks and glasses placed on the top and when I asked if they could place them on a tray so I could carry them back to the table, I was told in broken English "Self-service, you get tray, over there!" In terms of value, suffice it to say that we paid £94 for 5 sandwiches (which were nice and well filled but the rye was pre-sliced and too thin so it went very soggy and fell apart) plus 2 chips, 2 wings, 2 salads and 5 soft drinks. One final gripe if you can bare to carry on reading to the end, was being shouted at by 2 waitresses when ordering salad plates. There was an unwritten rule that said if you would like more than 2 salads you must pay for a 'portion' on smaller plates rather than put them on one big plate. One waitress took the plate from her colleague and scraped our food onto two smaller plates. We were passed objecting at that point and just watched bemused. Reubens are clearly trading on uniqueness of Kosher in town but they have forgotten that to remain in business, people want to come back. We won't.

rwfm8CLVrjOjuo6CMl0Akg.text: Definitely the best Salt Beef Sandwich in London. I have been here for lunch a few times with friends and the food always tastes great. Last couple of times we had this amazing soup with chicken meatballs and a little bit of thin noodles (sorry don't know the name) but it tasted great. Perfect for cold weather and goes well with the sandwich.  Will definitely recommend this place for an authentic salt beef sandwich.

3gXCcFfwK1AU4zRWIHC5tQ.text: I have been a patron of Reubens for years... literally more than a decade.  What it lacks in ambiance it makes up for in taste.  The food is delicious, the waitstaff, attentive.  Try the salt beef and the schnitzel.  If you have room, have the chicken soup... it literally is the best you can imagine.Cash for take out, credit cards for the restaurant downstairs.

_LgFiQs_SkW897xpEECEbA.text: the food was good but:2 shikabobs, a coke and a shred salad came to $70.

SBMsXK0NmR4W3piupRQ2uQ.text: As a frequent visitor to London who enjoys staying on Baker Street, I'd walked by this place many times, but didn't think I wanted a NYC Deli experience while in the UK.  However... a friend brought me here to dinner last night and I am IN LOVE.  This is a warm, friendly place, clean as a whistle, with a vintage vibe, and serving a very wide range of delicious, cooked-with-love (and Cordon Bleu training) foods which range from the classic Jewish deli corned beef (here "salt beef", and better than ours!) chopped liver, and fix-you-right-up chicken soup to elegant dinner offerings (in the more formal downstairs)  including the best lamb chops I have ever had.... with red wine ,spinach, and Apple Strudel for dessert (my friend had the chocoloate mousse).  In two meals I've tried many dishes and can't wait to return to try more.  They make a red current drink like a hot lemonade (name?) with lemon slices that apparently the Queen drinks.  Anyway, I'd never had this and it is terrific.  I'm bringing another friend tomorrow and that will make three days in a row.

PnpNgbnPsKMb7JB9wRjcYQ.text: The Reuben  at Reuben's  now this is a sandwich! For mighty sandwiches and Kosher delights, head to Reuben's in the heart of Marylebone on Baker Street.Don't like salt beef? Then you might as well stop reading now. But if you do like salt beef (and to like it is to love it!), by all means make yourself at home because I'm about to discuss a most glorious salt beef sandwich. It's the Reuben sandwich which is available at Reuben's restaurant, the West End's only Kosher restaurant. It's stacked to the sky with tomatoes, gherkins, sauerkraut, hot mustard and ample salt beef between two pieces of rye bread. The thing's so big it's almost impossible to hold with just two hands.Now, I'm not sure if this West End sarnie is a derivation of the American born deli classic by the same name or not, but there are definitely similarities. Salt beef is certainly a suitable British substitute for pastrami or corned beef (which you'd find mounds of within an American Reuben) and all the other ingredients are part of the American sandwich too. However, the US Reuben would have Swiss Cheese and/or Thousand Islands dressing (or some other dairy-based condiment) and our Baker Street version does not. I can only imagine that's simply to keep Kosher (by not mixing meat and dairy). Anyway, as much as I like the standard non-kosher US version, I'm more than content with this non-dairy Kosher style sandwich available at Reuben's. Beyond the massive sandwich, Reuben's is a brilliant setting for a meal. The cafeteria-esque counter service makes ya feel all retro and the Star of David logo-ed plates et al  along with the probability of there being more diners donning kippah skullcaps than not  offers an atmosphere that's more Tel Aviv or Lower East Side Manhattan than Central London. I've only been to Reuben's a few times, and each time I've had the Reuben (which will set ya back about nine quid). I'll go again (and soon!). I've never seen it packed, but I've never seen it even close to empty. It's a cool place with a particularly unique atmosphere for this side of Central London.

fjMLdXUUN7NMR6LXV84eSQ.text: We ate here twice while renting an apartment nearby and felt like we had been transported back to the Lower East Side of Manhattan. This strictly Glatt Kosher restaurant serves a soup loaded with pearl barley and butter beans that's a perfect antidote to a cold, damp day. Their version of Beef Wellington - a rib-eye steak slathered with chopped liver, then encased in pastry and topped with mushroom sauce - is to die for, and the fried chicken breast stuffed with fresh mango also is delectable. Their salt beef (corned beef to us Yanks) is nicely seasoned, not fatty, and possibly the best I've had. I don't remember ever seeing mince pie on a restaurant menu but they serve it here and it's delicious. Unlike the Jewish delis in New York, this one has ambience - they even have linen tablecloths! - and the service is polite and friendly and you won't feel rushed.

wjsJ2L3j_cg59J9df01Avg.text: If you are kosher and visiting London, Reuben's is going to be your lifesaver. The food is excellent, service generally excellent. Prices are, well, they know they are the only game in town but you are going to come out very satiated. All in all, very satisfactory!

Hoan6HkPavUD0xaiqgU2LA.text: Reubens is the only kosher restaurant in the heat of London and they know it... so here's what happen when there is little competition: super expensive, no credit card below £15, pickels on the side in an extra £1, no sandwich below £10Tab water is bad (yes, it's possible) and worth.. they announce you the extra pound for the pickle with a great smile.So take your time and go to Golders Green to have some decent kosher food.

hLaqwXbDOn2Qz1IChaKAgw.text: Is it authentic? Yes. Is it reasonably price? Yes.Is it better than Katz's Deli in NYC? No.I found the salt beef sandwich rather average compared to what I've had in NYC and elsewhere. Staff was helpful and friendly though.

Xf95A_vMCg4_GBjLFfQ7Vw.text: First, and to get it out of the way, yes, this is not a cheap meal.But for us it was worth it. Great, great kosher food in Central London. Not many options in this part of the city but this is a good one.My burger was outstanding. Made the way my Mother used to make burgers: fresh, well seasoned meat and just a hint of chopped onions. Outstanding.My boys and my wife all enjoyed their Jessica's week. Steak, Lamb Chops, and Sweet n Sour chicken. All great.And home made Pastrami (or Salt Meat as the Brits call it). Melt in your mouth delicious. The chef and the hostess (the chefs Mother) couldn't have been nicer. We wound up at a table next to friends of the chef and had a delightful conversation.The only reason Reuben's didn't get five stars from me is that the service was ever so slow. Not terrible, but not great (like everything else.That said: worth the time and expense.

kIcJ_40o6h6AC3c95sK2uA.text: A Reuben sandwich is pricey here, but the quality of the meet and rye bread makes it so worth it.

OoW5G1KuyX9cRihPTRaoFQ.text: The food was great. Coming from LA I know what great food is!  The only thing was a bit short was the service.  They had non English speaking staff taking your order....

dNBm1SUGzF5VxnjdHy1w2A.text: Heed to the advice on almost all other reviews for Reubens and stick to the upper-floor deli. Land early for lunch, or very late, for the place is super busy during peak lunch hours.Onto the food then--anything from the sandwiches portion of the menu is sure to leave you (a) full and (b) content. The meat is amazing, whatever it be. I generally stick to salt beef on rye with mustard. But a shoutout must go to the schnitzel, which is outstanding. Unlike a lot others I have had, this one's still moist on the inside--perfectly breaded and seasoned. It's a party in your mouth! And a mention to the humble chips. They are gorgeously thick cut, yet crunchy on the outside--a perfect accompaniment to the sandwiches.Nice place, warm people!

photos.caption: Photo of Reubens - London, United Kingdom. Schnitzel
Photo of Reubens - London, United Kingdom. Salt beef on rye, with mustard: the only correct way to have it
Photo of Reubens - London, United Kingdom. The chips are gorgeous

isbN6XlsDJChlD4MxCy_ZA.text: DO NOT EAT HERE! Both my mom and I ate here in March and got food poisoning from their signature Reuben sandwich! Like we got aggressive poisoning here. We should have know when we walked in during lunch hour and it was empty. Deli meats looked like they had been sitting there for a while but we gave it a shot because of the good reviews. Do yourself a favor and avoid this place at all costs!

e7dlgpz7j71sLz1kIVqO7w.text: The best chopped liver and salt beef sandwiches in the UK  pickles matzah and chicken soup. Oh my god I love it I would recommend anyone to come into here The food is delicious and tasty It's slightly expensive but the ambience will make up for it.

photos.caption: Photo of Reubens - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Reubens - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Reubens - London, United Kingdom

Ss3rKDqjYwsW_Mc3-tvY-w.text: As a card-carrying MOT I like to think I know a thing or two about deli. Sure, I regularly question the logic that people of a specific ethnicity are best suited to rate their own cuisine, I mean, my buddy Raj doesn't know fuck all about food, but suddenly his Indian recommendations are indubitable, utter bullshit.  Rueben's salt beef is great.  It's better than the Brass Rail at Selfridges by a shtetl mayl, which is actually one of two things I've had there, the other being matzo ball soup.  The matzo ball soup is not fantastic; the broth tastes instant and the kneidlach are heavy and not particularly flavourful. Annoyingly, if they run out of bagels they insist you buy a half or full sandwich which aren't as good a value, if £6.75 for a bagel sandwich can be considered a good deal.If you like to either feel very at home if you're Jewish, or probably kind of out of place if you're not, Reuben's is your spot!

8DxtNWSef7ESujqVN6khUA.text: Visited the Delhi section for lunch with my colleagues. The staff was very friendly and accommodating even though we turned up with 8 people during the busy lunch hour. Had the salt beef and fries - absolutely to die for. Will definitely come back next time in the neighbourhood.

At-29s1-arCoHs46bPTfrQ.text: My notion was correct: I'd vote for the deli upstairs. Downstairs is a bit stuffy and selection much more high end and expensive as my last review entailed. BUT THE DELI! OH THE DELI. Do it. Some colleagues and I popped in for a takeaway lunch a few days ago and were pleasantly there just as they opened for lunch (1130am). I went with a chopped liver sandwich (very rich), but really should've gone for the corned beef sandwich -- which is a MONSTER. The salads looked fresh and dense, and my lautchen was a super sweet treat with sultanas, vermicelli noodles and a bright yellow color. Delicious when warmed up! The "mom" of the shop was a true treat and she treated us like family! *10 percent off when using check in offer (upstairs deli only) via Yelp app. Loved my first visit to the deli, much different experience than upstairs.* Deli is cash only.

5e7VTluB98uK01VYS_rz_A.text: We popped in here for lunch on Colleen C's recommendation. I was a bit unsure as to how the place worked - here's my summary: join the end of the line, grab a tray and make your choice. I'd spied chicken schnitzel as we entered so I had to go for that. It was a little pricey (around £11) but it was worth it - it was nearly the size of the plate. They'll bring your food out to your table so don't stand around waiting (like we did!). The seating area is pretty casual and relaxed. Your meal is brought out to you so make sure you pick up cutlery when you're ordering. I really liked the chicken schnitzel, nicely crispy with a really tasty chicken breast inside. It came with a salad which I avoided but it looked nice and fresh. This place was great. Comfortable, relaxed, friendly and tasty food. You also get 10% off for checking in - the staff knew about this deal and seemed excited to have a bunch of Yelpers in. So make sure you use it! I'd definitely come back here as everyone who ate here (all 8 of us) were happy/overjoyed with their meals. Pretty great result in my opinion.

photos.caption: Photo of Reubens - London, United Kingdom. Chicken schnitzel

0iQixzhSj6WZ_sE3nLLQHg.text: This time we had fried codfish: good but bland. Unimpressive vegetables. Salt beef was again good, but it 's the kind of place a rabbi friend calls a "be glad we're here, kosher folks" restaurant. We skipped dessert--here..Takeout  foods are not measured by weight, but by container, which, of course, can be more or less full for the same price. Odd!

rjn9qdM-h5T1btzOHsWAyQ.text: We finally made it to Reubens, a real highlight amongst the ubiquitous and totally uninspiring high street chains lining Baker Street. On arrival we got a lovely welcome from a gentleman who appeared to be the owner, who also explained to us about some of the dishes on offer and about the more formal restaurant downstairs. We eat in the buzzing deli upstairs, which made a nice change eating dinner in an establishment offering the more informal yet hard to find (especially in the evening) counter service. We thoroughly enjoyed the salt beef sandwich, which was excellent, and the meatballs and the latke which I had never tried before washed down with kosher wine. The gentleman with who we spoke to on arrival also came up to us during our meal and asked if everything was okay, which it definitely was.We will definitely be back, and we're not even Jewish, so go on and give it a try whatever your faith.

lHTNwc702Qc5AbYFyBIivw.text: I rarely get to chow down Jew style like I did at Reubens. They had literally every delicacy from my childhood for me to ooh and ahh over, including the motherlode of all Jewy greatness -- gefilte fish.  My grandmother took the recipe for her homemade gefilte fish to the grave, so it is my proverbial "madeleine." Just one taste of a great gefitle can send me reeling back in time to my grandma's dining room table surrounded by aunts, uncles and cousins during our holiday family meet-ups. So when I spotted not one, but two kinds of gefilte at Reuben's I knew what I had to order. For variety sake, I chose the deep fried gefilte fish which I'd never seen before and it was amazing. Not greasy at all, the fish was the perfect consistency, delicately flavored and presented in elegant slices along with a ramekin of incredible homemade horseradish. Even my non-Jewish dining partners tried it and loved it, which is quite a statement. Every thing else we had at our table --from schnitzel and corned beef to hummous, beet salads and latkes -- was fantastic. Even though we enjoyed a 10% reduction thanks to their Yelp check-in offer, my one critique (and therefore the four instead of 5 stars) was the fact that they accept only cash, not easy when you're paying for a table of ten.

photos.caption: Photo of Reubens - London, United Kingdom. Fried Gefilte fish
Photo of Reubens - London, United Kingdom. Schnitzel
Photo of Reubens - London, United Kingdom. The Reubens!

odpWD4GIyvlZG6PuWqLl0g.text: THE place to go for corned beef ('salt beef' to the locals) in London. This place does it just as good as anything in New York. Sadly, the rye bread is a little lacking, reminding me of the texture (though not the taste) of Wonder Bread.Note: cash or debit card only. Also, because it's a strict kosher restaurant, there's no swiss cheese on your roast beef sandwich. It's the law. :-)

photos.caption: Photo of Reubens - London, United Kingdom. Salt beef (aka corned beef) on rye with some mustard
Photo of Reubens - London, United Kingdom. The deli counter - no cheese
Photo of Reubens - London, United Kingdom. Reubens on Baker Street

auU6O70ta-0LevPjmlwu0A.text: I enjoyed the ambiance and service very much here. The food was really tasty. I had the steak and requested that it be medium... and it was...We sat down for table service downstairs and received very nice service. The next day we even ate upstairs at the takeout deli. The food was delicious and very well done. Upstairs they only take cash, but there is a sign that says so..  so no worries there. Downstairs they do take visa and mastercard but not Amex.

8dN0MKHvErTDRjlW8c4q6w.text: Best salt beef sandwich (aka corned beef in the U.S.).  Hand carved piping hot. To die for. I've been back for the third time this month.

54bAqoV0eYhEu2xVCJynfQ.text: Normally I avoid kosher restaurants as they tend to be xerox copies of restaurants- a watered down affair which exists to serve a kosher version of a particular cuisine. A kosher deli is not so rare, and often they are good, but they are rarely good first and kosher second. This place however is outstanding. The fish and chips was a serving for two and the batter was golden brown and twice what's usually found. The brisket was fantastic. The schwarma was great although no better than at a good doner shop-- so the fact that it is kosher is the selling point for the schwarma. We ate only at the deli (upstairs) and I'd happily eat there again. Best fish/chips I ever tasted.
